com.github.blackjak34.compute.entity.tile

Class TileEntityComputer

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.minecraft.tileentity.TileEntity
      • com.github.blackjak34.compute.entity.tile.TileEntityComputer

  • public class TileEntityComputer
extends net.minecraft.tileentity.TileEntity
    The emulator component of the Computer block. Fully emulates an old 6502 processor from the '70s. Players can feed information into the computer through the GUI made available by BlockComputer.
    Since:
    1.0
    Author:
    Sam

    • Field Detail

      • screenBuffer

        private byte[][] screenBuffer
        The screen buffer, for an 80x50 character screen size. Writing a byte into this buffer will display a character on the screen accordingly.

      • registerA

        private byte registerA
        The registers within the 6502. Register A acts as the 'accumulator' and is primarily the target of most calculations, Register X and Y are mostly used for looping over data within memory and storing values temporarily, the processor flags are set and read by different instructions and affect their operation, and the stack pointer stores the address on page 1 where the next item on the stack may be stored. (The most recent value pushed to the stack may be found by reading the memory at location stackPointer - 1. The processor flags are as follows: 0 - Carry 1 - Zero 3 - Decimal Mode 4 - Break 5 - unused (always logical 1) 6 - Overflow 7 - Sign (negative)

      • registerX

        private byte registerX
        The registers within the 6502. Register A acts as the 'accumulator' and is primarily the target of most calculations, Register X and Y are mostly used for looping over data within memory and storing values temporarily, the processor flags are set and read by different instructions and affect their operation, and the stack pointer stores the address on page 1 where the next item on the stack may be stored. (The most recent value pushed to the stack may be found by reading the memory at location stackPointer - 1. The processor flags are as follows: 0 - Carry 1 - Zero 3 - Decimal Mode 4 - Break 5 - unused (always logical 1) 6 - Overflow 7 - Sign (negative)

      • registerY

        private byte registerY
        The registers within the 6502. Register A acts as the 'accumulator' and is primarily the target of most calculations, Register X and Y are mostly used for looping over data within memory and storing values temporarily, the processor flags are set and read by different instructions and affect their operation, and the stack pointer stores the address on page 1 where the next item on the stack may be stored. (The most recent value pushed to the stack may be found by reading the memory at location stackPointer - 1. The processor flags are as follows: 0 - Carry 1 - Zero 3 - Decimal Mode 4 - Break 5 - unused (always logical 1) 6 - Overflow 7 - Sign (negative)

      • flags

        private byte flags
        The registers within the 6502. Register A acts as the 'accumulator' and is primarily the target of most calculations, Register X and Y are mostly used for looping over data within memory and storing values temporarily, the processor flags are set and read by different instructions and affect their operation, and the stack pointer stores the address on page 1 where the next item on the stack may be stored. (The most recent value pushed to the stack may be found by reading the memory at location stackPointer - 1. The processor flags are as follows: 0 - Carry 1 - Zero 3 - Decimal Mode 4 - Break 5 - unused (always logical 1) 6 - Overflow 7 - Sign (negative)

      • stackPointer

        private byte stackPointer
        The registers within the 6502. Register A acts as the 'accumulator' and is primarily the target of most calculations, Register X and Y are mostly used for looping over data within memory and storing values temporarily, the processor flags are set and read by different instructions and affect their operation, and the stack pointer stores the address on page 1 where the next item on the stack may be stored. (The most recent value pushed to the stack may be found by reading the memory at location stackPointer - 1. The processor flags are as follows: 0 - Carry 1 - Zero 3 - Decimal Mode 4 - Break 5 - unused (always logical 1) 6 - Overflow 7 - Sign (negative)

      • programCounter

        private short programCounter
        The program counter. While at first glance this appears to be another register, the program counter is actually 16 bits instead of 8 to allow it to address up to 65536 bytes of memory. Every time the tile entity is updated (once per tick), the instruction at the location pointed to by the program counter is executed and the program counter is incremented by one (some instructions also change/increment the program counter during their operation, so the it may still change before it is incremented).

      • memory

        private byte[] memory
        The memory of the computer. This is represented with a byte array 65536 bytes in length.

      • state

        private StateComputer state
        The current state of the computer. This state may be 'RESET', 'HALT', or 'RUN'. While the computer only executes instructions while its state is RUN, RESET and HALT also serve to differentiate between the two settings for the front texture of the computer block. (see BlockComputer and StateComputer)

      • time

        private long time
        The amount of time that this tile entity has existed for. This is incremented every time the tile entity is updated, even if the computer is not in RUN mode. Because this is of 'long' type and it is incremented 20 times per second, it will roll over once every 14,623,560,433.9 years, which is roughly the same as the current age of the universe.

    • Constructor Detail

      • TileEntityComputer

        public TileEntityComputer()
        The constructor for an emulator instance. Fills the memory with #$FF and sets the unused flag to logical 1.

    • Method Detail

      • setBit

        private static byte setBit(byte target,
                           int offset,
                           boolean value)
        Sets a specific bit to a specified value within a byte. Mainly used for setting/unsetting the processor flags.
        Parameters:
        target - The byte value to be modified
        offset - Which bit to set
        value - The value to set the bit to
        Returns:
        The modified byte

      • testBit

        private static boolean testBit(byte target,
                               int offset)
        Tests a specific bit within a byte. Used primarily for determining the overflow/carry flags.
        Parameters:
        target - The byte to be tested
        offset - Which bit to test
        Returns:
        Whether or not that bit is set

      • readMemory

        private byte readMemory(short index)
        A helper function for accessing memory through a signed short variable (programCounter). Converts the value to unsigned by adding 32768 to it (max value of the short type) and returns the byte stored at that address.
        Parameters:
        index - The memory location to be read
        Returns:
        The byte at that location

      • writeMemory

        public void writeMemory(short index,
                        byte value)
        Similar in function to writeMemory, but writes the specified value to the memory location instead of reading from it.
        Parameters:
        index - The memory location to be written to
        value - The value to write

      • pushStack

        private void pushStack(byte value)
        Pushes a value to the stack. Adds 256 (decimal) to the stack pointer to put it on page 1, assigns the memory location at that address to the specified value, and decrements the stack pointer. This function does NOT check if the stack is full, and the stack pointer WILL overflow if pushed too frequently.
        Parameters:
        value - The value to be pushed.

      • pullStack

        private byte pullStack()
        Pulls a value off of the stack. Increments the stack pointer, adds 256 (decimal) to it to put it on page 1, and returns the byte stored at that address. This function does NOT check if the stack is empty, and the stack pointer WILL underflow if pulled too frequently.
        Returns:
        The value pulled off of the stack

      • setProgramCounter

        public void setProgramCounter(short value)
        Sets the program counter to the specified short value. This will cause the computer to start executing whatever instructions are stored at that location.
        Parameters:
        value - The address to jump to

      • setState

        public void setState(StateComputer state)
        Sets the computer's current state (see StateComputer). The state should always be changed through this function instead of directly because the metadata is also set accordingly.
        Parameters:
        state - The new state to use

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a String representation of this object. This includes the values of the A, X, and Y registers, as well as the stack pointer, and the number of times that this entity has been updated.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        A string representation of this emulator instance

      • writeToNBT

        public void writeToNBT(net.minecraft.nbt.NBTTagCompound data)
        Saves all of the data stored within this TileEntity into NBT format. Automatically called by Forge to save the data when the chunk containing this TileEntity is unloaded (by a player moving too far away, a player leaving the world, or the server shutting down).This function also appears to be called at arbitrary times during the game, so don't use it for running code that should be run on chunk unload.
        Overrides:
        writeToNBT in class net.minecraft.tileentity.TileEntity

      • readFromNBT

        public void readFromNBT(net.minecraft.nbt.NBTTagCompound data)
        Loads all of the data stored within an NBTTagCompound into this TileEntity accordingly. Automatically called by Forge to load the data when the chunk containing this TileEntity is loaded (by a player moving closer, a player joining the world, or the server starting up). This function also appears to be called at arbitrary times during the game, so don't use it for running code that should be run on chunk load.
        Overrides:
        readFromNBT in class net.minecraft.tileentity.TileEntity

      • updateEntity

        public void updateEntity()
        This function is automatically called by Forge once per tick for all loaded TileEntitys. This is the main work function of the emulator; it increments the time and executes an instruction every time the TileEntity is updated. You may also call this function manually if you want the emulator to asynchronously execute a command.
        Overrides:
        updateEntity in class net.minecraft.tileentity.TileEntity
